Welcome everyone, 

I am new here and hope that this is the right place to =
announce a novel JUnit extensions. If not, please point us to the proper 
p=
lace.

JExample is an extensions that introduces dependencies. But unlike e=
g TestNG, we go  beyond mere dependencies. We use 
dependencies to pass the=
 "instance under test" from one the test method to the next. If test B depe=
nds on A, the return value of A 
can be used as B's fixture. And if A test =
fails, B and all other dependees of A are skipped and marked as white. We s=
how in an 
empirical study (accepted at the XP2008 conference) that JExampl=
e improves performance, shortness of test methods, and defect 
localization=
.

Let me give an example :)

Testing a stack is not trivial, there is an i=
ntrinsic dependency between pushing and popping elements. An element can no=
t be 
popped without pushing it first. Intrinsic dependencies are evil. If =
there is a bug in push, both push's and pop's test fail, even if 
there is =
no bug in pop! Therefore, we declare that testPop depends on the successful=
 outcome of testPush. When running the 
tests, the return value of testPush=
 is used as the fixture of testPop.

@Test
public Stack testPush() {
      =
Stack s =3D new Stack();
      s.push("Foo");
      assertEquals(1, s.size(=
));
      return s;
}

@Test
@Depends("testPush")
public void testPop(Stack=
 s) {
      s.pop("Foo");
      assertEquals(0, s.size());
}

Using JExampl=
e, each test method is a comprehensive constructor that creates an example =
instance of the unit under test. That is 
also why JExample is called JExam=
ple. The idea of example-driven testing is based on the work of Markus Gael=
li.
